bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, January 18, 1946

div1.p: Lambert expresses great disappointment for the lack of recognition, in Truby's book, of his work at the yellow fever camp.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, January 18, 1946
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Chicago, Illinois
January 18, 1946
General Albert E. Truby
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I have often thought of writing a few remarks on your book.
Now when I know it from cover to cover, have read it at least
twenty times, if I am going to write must do it now as I am
going blind (left eye has been dead for over 20 years, right
is going fast).

If it was in my power to change, I would change it to read that
Dr. Ames had yellow fever contracted during the work. I have his
service record from the Adj. General's Office. I would mention
that Dr. Ames was carried on his bed when he himself was sick
with yellow fever a quarter of a mile to attend one of the ex-
perimental cases when patient was neglected by the doctor in
charge. I would scratch off buildings 17, 18, 19 & 20 from the
hospital plan because they were never there. The drawing I sent
was correct. I volunteered to go down there two weeks before
Maj. Kean came down, when packmaster and his wife came in with
yellow fever and lived there until March 2nd, and could not help
but see the buildings if they had been there. I was outside of
the quarantine line only the two nights Dr. Ames sent me to help
with Dr. Carroll. There was a 36-36 box without door put up
over a hole for a toilet after Christmas. Oh yes, I was on Dr.
Carroll's case all right, although only two nights, but I think
they were criticial nights. Dr. Carroll was in great distress
and out of his head, wanted to get out of bed. I came in the
room and put him back. The nurse only said “Dr. Carroll you
shouldn't get out of bed.” Could Dr. Carroll, if he had been
allowed to get up and walk around, have strained himself and
brought on black vomit? As described in Book “Maj. Reed and
Yellow Fever”, told by Warner how she hung on Dr. Lezear's
back. I might be wrong, but I claim a little credit in Carroll's
recovery.

If I could I would like to change the statement on page 81, the
word “most” I would replace with “all” and there were no other
non-immunes. There were two women, Gillen and McCook, both
immunes, there to care for female patients, of which we had only
two, one before and one right after Maj. Kean, and I took care
of them. I can't remember if Gillen and McCook came down right
after Christmas or not. Most likely the toilet was put up on
their account, but I do know they were there long enough to
transform one-half box of new sheets into ladies' underwear.
Silk was not for common people in those days. Dr. Ames never
put them to work but the Doctor who substituted for Ames did,
taking care of Andrus. How they performed their duty, the en-
closed carbon copy will tell in part. Andrus has made a mis-
take where he states I was on night duty and Gillen and McCook
took care of him. I had Folks and Forbes in “15”, Ames in “13”
for three days only. Andrus was in “16” when Gillen came and
asked me to come over and tie Andrus because he was “awful”,
-2-
and I found the boy in great distress due to not passing any
urine in over eight hours. When I asked if she had tried to
catherize. I did not hear if she said “I couldn't do that”
or “I wouldn't do that. Anyway, I went after a catherer and
drew 710 c.c. from the boy. I remember the quantity because
I later reported to Dr. Ames. He always preached “Watch
the urine.” When called three day's later by Gillen, she
said she knew that he was only cranky. I thought he was
real sick but did not know the trouble. I ran up to the hospital,
with Ames' permission, and the help of McCarthy carried Ames down
to look at Andrus. Dr. found a rectal carbuncle that needed
cutting. When I took Dr. Ames out of the room the nurse was not
there, but when we came back an hour later both the nurse and
Maj. Stark acted as a reception committee. As soon as the bed was
on the floor the storm broke loose. I never had a better calling
down in all my life. Maj. Stark was really angry. Maj. Stark
took care of Ames after he was sent up to the hospital. Maj.
Stark's anger was only temporary. He was very kind to me after
I was released from quarantine. I was the last man he operated
on before leaving Cuba. I went on the table at 9 A.M. At 1 P.M.
he left for Washington. I never had a chance to thank him for
ridding me of a rupture. Even the review article in “The Military
Surgeon” took the credit away from me, if any credit was due, by
saying “did not undergo any hazardous test.” That might have
pertained to Neate. It would have been his own fault if he had
been careless with the mosquitos but the formitos test, I had
more of that than all the rest of the men put together. Besides
we had a few bad mosquitos too. Dr. Carroll gave me two test
tubes with 8 or 10 mosquitos in them to be turned loose with
Martinez. He wouldn't let them feed any on him while he was awake.
They were all lost but two. I will never believe anything else
but that it was one of those lost mosquitos that inoculated Dr.
Ames.

Black vomit by which the Stark boys were messed up, came from a
man named Sullivan. He wasn't an experimental case but Dr. Ames
told me to save some for Dr. Carroll's laboratory. The autopsy
mentioned, which Dr. Carroll attended shortly after his recovery,
was on a Sargeant of the 2nd Art. Dr. Reed, Carroll, Ames and
Agramonte were there. I assisted Agramonte in the work. After
the doctors had what they wanted, I prepared the body for burial.
When ready I went to the door. (Battery and band lined up for
immediate funeral). I asked someone to give me a hand placing
body in casket but none would come in so I had to dump the body
in and then straighten it out. These two cases were not experi-
mental cases but they were both used by the commission in the
experiment. When Sullivan had black vomit the third time Maj.
Gorgas was standing longside the bed. When I reached under the
bed for the pan he spewed over my head. Maj. Gorgas grabbed a
towel hanging on the bed and threw over me so I could wipe my
face. I was blinded. Maj. Gorgas asked if I had any disinfectant
to go and wash at once. Three days later Maj. Gorgas called and
asked why the last death hadn't been reported. When I told him
we hadn't had any he mentioned Sullivan's name. I answered that
-3-
he was sitting up in bed. The Major couldn't believe it so had
to come out and see for himself. The Major told Sullivan that
he had never before seen a man his age (64) have black vomit
three times and recover. The four men who took formito tests
only volunteered after being offered extra pay. None would volunteer
to go in as nurse when first patient came to pesthouse.

Senator Thomas of Utah was right when he wrote in Senate report
on my bill, “This man should have quit when the first case of
experimental yellow fever came in. He would then have been asked
to volunteer to nurse the experimental cases as he had previously
volunteered to nurse natural cases.” I was no “heel”. Men were
sick and needed care. If Maj. Reed had been alive when bill to
grant recognition was passed, I know my name would have appeared
with the rest. I was wrong. Dr. Pinto did not attend Andrus
and would have known so if I had only looked at the group picture.
The enclosed carbon copy will show where Andrus wrote in the name
Pinto, 3rd line from bottom. Little Andrus was a prince. He
plugged for my bill by writing to many Senators and members of
the House. It was a real disappointment to him, as well as to
myself, when bill after passing the Senate, both committees of
the House, was returned to committee for reconsideration and
allowed to die there.

The doctor who attended Andrus was dark complected, somewhat
pale, Dr. Lezeare's height, lean, it seems to me he had dark
beard and wore glasses. Please tell me if you can name him
after this description. Could I have been Dr. de Poorter men-
tioned in the book? Enclosed to show how Andrus felt about my
bill. Please return carbon copy. Carbon copies sent just to
show how Andrus felt
regarding my work
div1.closer:
Respectfully, (signed) Gust E. Lambert
8009 Avalon Ave.
Chicago 19, Ill. GL:MO
